Augustine of Hippo's "On Christian Doctrine" is a work that discusses how Christians should interpret and understand the Bible. In this work, Augustine argues that understanding the meaning of words is essential to interpreting the Bible correctly. He believed that the meaning of words can be divided into two types: signification and application.

Signification refers to the relationship between a word and the concept or thing it represents. Augustine believed that words have fixed meanings and that these meanings are determined by convention. For example, he writes, "When we say 'ox,' we signify that quadruped of which this name is the common appellation" (Book II, Chapter 6). Augustine argued that understanding the signification of words was crucial to understanding the Bible, as it allowed readers to grasp the meaning of important terms and concepts.

Application, on the other hand, refers to the way in which words are used in a particular context. Augustine believed that words could be used in different ways depending on the context in which they were used. He wrote, "When we say 'He emptied himself,' we use the word 'emptied' in an unusual and metaphorical sense" (Book III, Chapter 3). Augustine argued that understanding the application of words was crucial to understanding the Bible, as it allowed readers to understand the nuances of language and the way in which words can be used to convey multiple meanings.

In "On Christian Doctrine," Augustine also discussed the importance of understanding the historical and cultural context in which the Bible was written. He believed that understanding the context in which the Bible was written was essential to interpreting it correctly. For example, he wrote, "Whoever takes another meaning out of Scripture than the writer intended goes astray, but not through any falsehood in Scripture" (Book III, Chapter 18).

Overall, Augustine's view on the study of word meanings was that understanding the signification and application of words was essential to interpreting the Bible correctly. He believed that words had fixed meanings, but that they could also be used in different ways depending on the context. Augustine also stressed the importance of understanding the historical and cultural context in which the Bible was written.
